metadata.case_name: State of Assam v. C. Dey

facts.text: Appeal filed by State of Assam against judgment and order dated July 16, 1956 of Assam High Court at Gauhati in Civil Rule No. 128 of 1954.
High Court held that s. 15 of the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947, and Rule 80 framed under the Act were ultra vires Art. 286(2) of the Constitution.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 132(1) of the Constitution.
C. Dey is a wholesale dealer in tea, in business since 1949.
C. Dey registered as a dealer under Assam Sales Tax Act on January 14, 1950.
C. Dey's business consists mainly of buying tea in Assam and selling it either in Assam or in Calcutta.

In respect of tea sold in Calcutta, C. Dey consigns the tea to himself after purchasing in Assam; tea is then approved by prospective purchasers to whom documents of title are endorsed on receipt of price.
Assam Sales Tax Act amended in 1951 by Assam Sales Tax Amendment Act 4 of 1951.

Before amendment, s.15 provided that in calculating net turnover of registered dealer, all sales to another registered dealer of goods specified in latter's certificate were excluded from gross turnover if goods bought for resale.
1951 amendment added words 'in the State' after 'resale' in s.15, so only goods intended for resale in the State excluded from gross turnover.

Rule 80 enacted post-amendment: Dealer wishing to deduct sales under s.15(1)(b) must produce cash memo/bill and declaration by purchasing dealer that goods for resale in the State, specified in registration certificate.
C. Dey filed petition under Art. 226 challenging amendment and Rule as ultra vires Art. 286(2), Part XIII, and Art. 19(1)(g).
Art. 19(1)(g) and Part XIII objections abandoned.
High Court Chief Justice held amendment and Rule tax sales in course of inter-State trade/commerce.
Ram Labhaya J. held sales to C. Dey not in course of inter-State trade; but s.15 fails to incorporate exclusion in machinery for net turnover, leading to indirect taxation of inter-State sales.
s.3 amended by Act 4 of 1951 introducing sub-s.(1A) excluding sales outside State, in import/export, or inter-State trade/commerce.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.15 as amended by Act 4 of 1951 and Rule 80 are ultra vires Art. 286(2) of the Constitution.
Whether amendment and Rule directly or indirectly tax sales in course of inter-State trade or commerce.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sales by C. Dey inside Assam to himself are intra-State, not in course of inter-State trade; subsequent sales in Calcutta are separate.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286(2); Endupuri Narasimham Son v. State of Orissa

petitioner_arguments.text: s.3(1A) excludes inter-State sales from charging section; no need for repetition in machinery s.15; inter-State sales immune via Art. 286(2) and s.3(1A).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Assam Sales Tax Act s.3(1A), s.15; Art. 286

petitioner_arguments.text: s.15 grants additional exemption for intra-State resales to avoid multi-point taxation.

respondent_arguments.text: Amendment and Rule tax sales in course of inter-State trade/commerce (Chief Justice view).
Though s.3 excludes inter-State sales, s.15 as machinery section does not incorporate exclusion; non-exclusion from gross turnover leads to taxation of inter-State sales via net turnover.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Assam Sales Tax Act s.3, s.15; Art. 286(2)

court_reasoning.text: Rejects Chief Justice's view: Transactions wholly inside Assam; sales to self in Assam are intra-State, separate from Calcutta sales; follows Endupuri Narasimham.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only sales affecting inter-State trade directly are protected; purchases inside State taxable.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects Ram Labhaya J.: s.3(1A) repeats Art.286 prohibitions in charging section, excluding inter-State sales; no need for machinery s.15 repetition; inter-State sales immune regardless of net turnover calculation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.3(1A) saves transactions from taxation; Art.286 prevails.

court_reasoning.text: s.15 provides additional exemption for registered dealer-to-dealer sales for resale in State to avoid multi-point taxation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Net turnover calculation does not override constitutional/charging exclusions.

holdings.text: s.15 as amended and Rule 80 are not ultra vires Art. 286(2); intra-State sales to registered dealers taxable unless for resale in State.
Sales inside State are intra-State even if goods later sold outside; inter-State sales excluded by s.3(1A) and Art.286.

precedents_cited.case_name: Endupuri Narasimham Son v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Held intra-State purchases taxable despite later inter-State sales; applies directly to facts.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: s.3(1A) excludes inter-State sales; s.15 machinery for net turnover excludes intra-State resales.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Sales Tax (Amendment) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s.15 to limit exclusion to resales 'in the State'; added s.3(1A).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 286(2) prohibits State tax on inter-State sales; others challenged but abandoned.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; s.15 as amended and Rule 80 held intra vires and valid.

key_quotes.text: "The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Assam... The present levy is not on the sales by the [dealer] to persons outside the State, but on the purchases by him inside the State."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes intra-State sales from inter-State; applies precedent.

key_quotes.text: "What has already been excluded by the operation of the Constitution and the Act cannot become taxable, because the net turnover has to be calculated in a particular manner."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies charging section exclusions prevail over machinery provisions.
